awd_titl_txt: Human Response To State Collapse And Social Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Nicola Sharratt and Dr. Charles Spencer will examine the long-term impacts of violent state collapse. The breakdown of complex societies is a recurring process in the human past and present. While existing archaeological research has substantially advanced understanding of why and how states fragment, it has focused primarily on the immediate political and economic outcomes. By examining social dynamics that occurred over several centuries following the collapse of one of the earliest states in Andean South America, the Tiwanaku (AD 500-1000), this project investigates the lasting repercussions of political disintegration for social cohesion, instability, and cultural continuity. Bringing together an international team of specialists from the United States and Peru the project will provide training opportunities for American and Peruvian students, as well as data for theses and dissertations. 

As in many other examples of state collapse, although Tiwanaku's disintegration resulted in radical changes in political and economic organization, considerable continuity is evident in the ways that people lived their daily lives, the materials and architecture they constructed and the rituals they enacted. This continuity has been clearly demonstrated at the site of Tumilaca la Chimba, located in southern Peru. The site was first established around AD 1000 by refugees fleeing the turmoil of Tiwanaku state collapse. Previous research shows that although the site's inhabitants lived through drastic political change, they maintained Tiwanaku ways of life and cultural practices for more than two hundred years. However, around AD 1250, Tiwanaku materials and practices disappear from the site and from the region more broadly. The research will investigate the social processes that resulted in the drastic disappearance of Tiwanaku affiliated communities after several centuries of cultural continuity and resilience. 

Researchers will test whether the Tiwanaku affiliated population abandoned the site, was displaced by outsiders, or was assimilated into a new community. The validity of each of these explanations will be determined by characterizing the nature of the relationship between the Tiwanaku affiliated population at Tumilaca la Chimba, and the population who inhabited it after AD 1250. This will be achieved by excavating and analyzing data from the post-AD 1250 occupation that is comparable to that for the Tiwanaku affiliated community. By excavating houses and burials, investigating diet, craft production, and ritual practice researchers will determine whether the two communities shared a cultural identity. Through osteological analyses, particularly of genetically determined dental traits, researchers will examine whether the two populations were biologically related. By extensively radio-carbon dating archaeological contexts researchers will investigate whether the two populations ever co-existed at the site. Political collapse is a process that affects societies in numerous geographical, temporal, and cultural contexts. Building on existing research on the short-term impacts that socio-political disruption has on communities, this project takes a long-term perspective to investigate how populations can be affected by and respond to such turmoil for centuries.

por.por_cntn:
Project Goals: The collapse of political states affects societies in diverse geographical, temporal, and cultural contexts. Recurrent in the past and present, collapse will continue to happen. Examining ancient state collapse offers opportunities to learn from the past and build models to prepare for the future. With its ability to examine long time periods and people often ignored in written histories, archaeology is uniquely suited to reconstructing the long-term impacts of state collapse. Through extensive excavation, analysis, and the integration of new technologies in archaeological science, this project reconstructed social dynamics that occurred over several centuries following the collapse of one of the earliest states in Andean South America (the Tiwanaku). By doing so, it investigated the lasting repercussions of political disintegration for social cohesion, instability, and cultural continuity.

Case Study: The Tiwanaku state exerted cultural, economic, and political influence over large areas of the southern Andes between AD 600 and 1000 but underwent a drawn out and violent collapse beginning around AD 1000. The PI’s previous work at the site of Tumilaca la Chimba, in southern Peru, demonstrated considerable post-collapse continuity in daily and ritual practice, material styles and architecture despite radical changes in regional social organization. The site was first established around AD 1000 by refugees fleeing the turmoil of Tiwanaku state collapse who maintained Tiwanaku ways of life for more than two hundred years. However, around AD 1250, Tiwanaku materials disappear from the site and from the broader region. The current project investigated the social processes that resulted in the drastic disappearance of Tiwanaku affiliated communities after several centuries of cultural continuity and resilience. Specifically, through field and lab work conducted between 2015 and 2018, it tested whether the Tiwanaku affiliated population abandoned the site, was displaced by outsiders, or was assimilated into a new community.

Project Activities: The validity of each explanation was tested by characterizing the nature of the cultural, the biological, and the temporal relationships between the Tiwanaku affiliated population at Tumilaca la Chimba and the population who inhabited it after AD 1250. This was achieved by collecting data from the post-AD 1250 occupation and comparing it to the PI’s existing pre-AD 1250 data. To collect the post-AD 1250 data, the team conducted two seasons of excavation. In 2015, the team excavated three houses in their entirety as well as eight burials. In 2016 (with some additional funding from the Archaeological Institute of America and the Brennan Foundation), the team conducted further cemetery excavations, resulting in a sample of 21 burials. Beginning in 2016 and continuing until 2018, the lab components of the project were completed. These included analyses of the excavated materials (human remains, pottery, stone tools, faunal/animal bones, textiles, and plant remains). Analyses were undertaken by experts in each material type. Analysis  included collecting data on non-metric dental traits from human remains in order to undertake bio-distance analyses and reconstruct biological relationships between the two populations; radiometric dating using AMS of 29 samples to reconstruct temporal relationships between the two populations; Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry of pottery sherds which analyses the chemical composition of pottery and facilitated studying craft production after AD 1250. 

Project Conclusions: The analyses of daily (e.g. diet, craft production) and ritual practice, as well as architectural patterns suggested that despite stark stylistic changes, the post-AD 1250 population incorporated elements of pre-AD 1250 lifeways. The analyses of genetically determined dental traits indicated that the two populations were biologically related, and that the post-AD 1250 population descended, at least in part, from the pre-AD 1250 population. The radio-carbon dates revealed that the two occupations overlapped. In sum, the data support the hypothesis that the Tiwanaku affiliated population was assimilated into a new community around AD 1250. This suggests that although the initial refugee population maintained an identity rooted in Tiwanaku ancestry for 200 years, the longer-term impacts of collapse were a process of ethnogenesis and identity shift. 

Training and Dissemination: At every stage, the project provided training opportunities for undergraduates and graduate students, through participation in field and lab-work and by generating data for student research project and theses. Undergraduate participation was funded through NSF Research Experience for Undergraduate supplemental awards. The majority of students who trained on the project were enrolled at either Georgia State University or the University of Illinois at Chicago. These institutions are large, urban, public schools that are both noted for their success in serving ethnically and economically diverse student populations.
Dissemination of results is ongoing but to date has included presentation at professional conferences (international and national; by the PI and other project specialists also by student team members), publication in high-impact scholarly venues, to local community members and officials through talks and site visits, and to public audiences in the USA through invited public talks.
